Reviews.Author: Amy H.
Reviews.Content: Have not had a bad meal here yet!!! Highly recommend the Veal Marsala DELICIOUS!!! I never eat a whole meal and I usually box half of it to go for the husband but I ate EVERY single bite of this thing!! Their pizzas are fantastic! My favorite is Pizza Bianca!! So simple yet SO good! Authentic pizza!! Love their Bruschetta, and their calamari is standard calamari but the sauce that comes with it is great. Now let's talk lasagna, maybe  I have not had good lasagna but this thick piece of deliciousness is DELICIOUS!  I usually order a to-go one and pop it in the oven at home to share with the hubby ON TOP of what I order there. I never say no to it. SO good!! The service is great, wine selection is great, and the atmosphere is great! Overall great great great!

Reviews.Author: Lawrence C.
Reviews.Content: Crabcake appy $10, as was the insalata w/ Gorgonzola cheese.  Linguini pescatore $19, was reasonable plate. Various tastings of wines by the glass until we found one we liked; $9/glass. Timothy (head waiter?) took excellent care of us.Not a destination restaurant, but very good for when you're in the midtown/theater area.

Reviews.Author: Jim L.
Reviews.Content: I have long said that Baraonda is about the best Italian in Atlanta. I haven't been to every place that serves all of the regional Italian fare, but it's hard to imagine better than here. I first ate here after seeing 'Phantom of the Opera' next door at the Fox, and have been back several times since. Wonderful food, service, choices, and such. Never had bad food or experiences here. Plus Jim's Pizza Tour invaded on September 27, 2013, and got one of the most amazing pizza's ever. Topped with prociutto! Oh, my, it was so good. Maybe top 5 of all time.  Perfect place for you and your date on a Fox Theatre night.

Reviews.Author: Arlene R.
Reviews.Content: Sorry after reading rave reviews I was disappointed. I have Lingini with seafood and husband had a sausage dish which he said was bitter because of the greens. The service was just ok  wouldn't break my neck to return. Others seemed happy may be it was just us.

Reviews.Author: Kawika V.
Reviews.Content: Baraonda has always been a favorite of mine. They really get the whole picture here. The atmosphere, the food, the service all impeccable. You simply must try the Lasagna and the tiramisu. I trot down here just for the tiramisu.

Reviews.Author: Regina S.
Reviews.Content: Took out of town guests here and had a wonderful experience. The food was very tasty; we usually add salt and didn't need to add a thing. For first courses- the salads were fresh and a nice blend of ingredients.  Entrees- margarita pizza was outstanding, house made ravioli was full of flavor, but did need a bit more heat (temperature) and linguini with mixed seafood was crazy good. Would recommend.

Reviews.Author: Wendell B.
Reviews.Content: Stopped in for "lupper" with our best friends, prior to seeing "Evita" at the Fox (less than a block away.0  My wife ordered her favorite caprese salad, which she devoured,  and two of us had the house salad with a delicious balsamic viniagrette.  For our entree, I ordered my favorite, lasagna, and it was so tasty I wanted to pick up the skillet it was served in and lick it, but I restrained myself.  My wife had the Pollo, a organic white chicken breast with fennel, olives and cherry tomatoes served over sauteed spinach.  Bred was crispy and replenished.  The food and service were impeccable, but it was a little too pricey for us, but the convenience outweighed the price.  We would go again with the right company, as we had this time.

Reviews.Author: John H.
Reviews.Content: Terrific try the Caper Island Clams... excellent. Excellent wine list. Service was attendant without being intrusive.  Not a large menu but all five dishes in my group were well received.

Reviews.Author: Steven P.
Reviews.Content: The meal was great. I had the pizza made in their brick oven and it was very well prepared. My friend had a pasta dish with shrimp and he said that it was delicious.

Reviews.Author: Greg E.
Reviews.Content: Weak , rude servers , slow service...   cold soup. The upside , cold beer . On your way to the Fox theatre ... Go anywhere else.

Reviews.Author: David M.
Reviews.Content: Well just a couple weeks before I move away from Atlanta and finally had experiences here that took it off my favorite spots in Atlanta.First a plus.. its finally on OpenTable.  Though honestly I'm fairly convinced they block out good reservation times because of the Fox.Which leads me to the bad and what will unfortunately taint my memories and opinions of Baraonda.  Since the last time I've eaten here they have enacted a new policy to have a limited menu at dinner.  The nice extensive list of pizzas are gone and relegated to the lunch menu.  That left maybe 6 that could be ordered for dinner.  I was told tonight that because of how busy nights are when there are shows at the Fox, they decided to limit the options to make sure customers get quick service.  Unfortunately for me that means that the primary reason I'm going there was taken away.  Was craving their Bianca pizza all day (since I really don't like red sauce pizzas) and was told that I couldn't get it for dinner anymore.  Very disappointing for what was my favorite pizza place in town.

Reviews.Author: Coleen F.
Reviews.Content: This place has a young hip vibe. I came in to get something to eat only (no drinks) since I had to work that evening. The person greeting me at the door told me to sit at the bar because they were expecting a large theater crowd coming in. So I sit and wait. And wait. Two servers were having a conversation behind the bar. I guess I was intruding. I was finally asked what I wanted to drink and when I said water, he acted like I was a waste of space. Sorry dude, my company does random drug & alcohol testing. I decided to order a Romano pizza to go and get the h*** out of there.  Prosciutto, cheese, caramelized onions and sun dried tomato on a thin crust. The pizza was decent, but $15 for a medium size pie and toppings were scarce. Also, they need to look up the meaning of caramelized. It doesn't mean "translucent & and still crunchy", which is the way theirs was prepared. I won't be back.

Reviews.Author: S P.
Reviews.Content: We had their pizza and pasta (farfella) and they were very good.  Good quality ingredients and nice atmosphere, will be coming back!

Reviews.Author: Phil H.
Reviews.Content: I'll start somewhat positive. The ambiance is nice. Good mood lighting. Pleasant background music. Decently nice setup. In fact, ambiance is nice enough that I would have given the place three stars but for the fact that I saw a man's dick while I was eating my calamari. Yes, while sitting at a table facing the intersection of Peachtree and 3rd, I happened to look up at one point and notice a homeless man urinating in the bushes outlining the restaurant. Certainly not Baraonda's fault, but hey, stars have to be docked anytime we're talking about a man's cock in the middle of a restaurant review. Lots of panhandlers outside, too, so I wouldn't be surprised if it's the first time the restaurant's bushes have been used as a Starbucks bathroom. As for the food, it's ridiculously blah. As usual, Atlanta cannot get Italian food right. First of all, Atlanta Italian restaurant chefs: it's called SUGAR. Please use some in your red sauces. The lack of such ingredient made for a terrible seafood linguini - tart isn't even the word to begin to describe that sauce. The calamari was rubbery and bland, which actually keeps me from complaining about the minuscule portion they serve. The Margherita Pizza looked and tasted straight out of Chuck E. Cheese. The cheese even strung like it, too, which everyone knows should never happen with a Margherita Pizza.Oh, and parking. It's free up to two hours. Only thing is, you have to park down the street and get your ticket validated. Don't enjoy the ambiance too much and end up staying in there for longer than two hours and end up paying for parking. Wait staff is nice, but long story short, this place is totally overpriced, bland, and frankly, not that good. I'm not coming back. Wish I never went in the first place.

Reviews.Author: Nichole K.
Reviews.Content: I've been here numerous times especially since I work next to the restaurant and it's always a nice place to go before a show at the Fox.I've always had great service. The selection is small, but it is good. Their pizza's are excellent and they also have really nice small plates and salads. My advice for going here before a show at the Fox.It's going to be very crowded. You probably won't get a table if your not there very early or have reservations. Unless, this is a personal favorite restaurant or a tradition before seeing a show at the Fox, I would suggest another place that isn't so close to avoid the crowds.

Reviews.Author: Michael W.
Reviews.Content: Owner was also the owner of Enoteca Carbonari which shared the SAME address.  He issued coupons in lieu of paying for radio ads. He closed off that part of the restaurant but did honor the coupons for a time once he closed it down.      Coupon has NO EXPIRATION date. Yesterday he referred to Enoteca Carbonari as "them" when it is indeed HIM and refuses to honor.  He also owns Publik Draft house there on the corner of Ponce and Fig Jam.   It's just a bad business practice, and to imply that wasnt him is unacceptable. People know its the same owner, and its in comments right here on yelp under Enoteca Carbonari also. Photo posted

Reviews.Author: Kevin L.
Reviews.Content: The rustic limestone walls and open wine collection make this a great location for an intimate get together, but the quality of the food ruins the entire ambiance. We had the clamcowder, linguini pescatore, margherita pizza, and fra diavolo. The clamchowder was only luke warm and had a strange after taste. I was expecting far more because it was the night's special. The linguini pescatore was even worse. The noodles were completely undercooked (not even aldente), and the seafood wasn't fresh. The flatbread pizzas were honestly not bad, but I was already so disappointed with my dinner that I couldn't enjoy them.I called before walking into Baraonda, believing that there would be a long wait at 7pm on a Saturday night. There were only 4 tables occupied. I should've known from that moment that something was wrong.I may come back to Baraonda in the future, but I'll stick to the pizzas.

Reviews.Author: Ryan A.
Reviews.Content: Smug. That's the word that comes to mind when you are first greeted by the maître d'. Most of the people dining here, including us, only went here because of it's vicinity to the Fox Theatre. There was no reason to become a regular here - the food is overpriced for what it is. Don't get me wrong - I am more than willing to pay for good Italian food. We ordered the calamari as an appetizer and though the flavor was just okay, it was indeed cooked correctly. One of us ordered a lasagna and commented it was just better than a microwaveable Stouffer's frozen, boxed dinner. Everybody else weren't blown away from our food. They don't have any right to be smug about their restaurant. The only reason they are packed is because people need a place to eat dinner before watching a show. If an Olive Garden was to replace them, I bet you they'd be packed too.

Reviews.Author: Marcia W.
Reviews.Content: Beings we made reservation on Yelp we were put on different waiting list and waited an hour for our table. Their policy with online reservations. Ordered Linguine Pescatore and for $22. there should have been a lot more seafood in it. Small portion and salty. Expected a nice crusty Italian bread with good EVOO. The soft bread served wasn't worth eating and neither was oil on table. Didn't see much of our waiter either. IF we ever go back  it'll be for appetizers or to try a pizza. Better service and less wait next door at the Fox!!

Reviews.Author: Liz V.
Reviews.Content: Baraonda is a very dimly lit, romantic restaurant. The dark wood café tables with white tablecloths, large framed Italian pictures and soft tea candles at every table added to the ambiance. We came off of bustling Peachtree Street and were transported to a quiet, soft spoken restaraunt. It may have been who I was with, but this place is magic at night.We ordered the bruschetta, a pizza, a side of stuffed olives and a few strong drinks. The drinks were a random nightly special; something pink and fruity that brought on the giggles and a few hair tosses.The bruschetta was made with thick, crusty bread and topped with a chunky mix of tomatoes, olive oil, garlic and cilantro. The appetizer was a meal in its own and we couldn't finish it.The pizza we ordered had artichoke hearts, olives and prosciutto. I only wish I knew the name as it was on the menu-I blame the drinks. After my 3rd martini, I was pleased to have the thin crust to keep my head from spinning. Their pizza is baked in their custom pizza oven that cooks the dough evenly, leaving the pizza so fresh and crusty you lick your fingers between bites. The food portions were out of control! We left with 2 boxes of leftovers, which made for an excellent cold pizza breakfast. I only wish Baraonda had more locations and were OTP. What a fabulous, little place!

Reviews.Author: Theresa S.
Reviews.Content: I am rarely in midtown during the week for lunch.  But today I was, so I wanted to give Baraonda a whirl.I enjoyed the food but agree the service is hit or miss.Hits:  Fresh tomato sauce on my Margarita pizza.  Simple and classic.  I got the lasagna to go for later and despite a little reheating in the microwave, it held together very nicely.  Chunks of carrots in the bolognese, layers of thin al dente pasta (even after sitting around for a bit!) - cheese and sauce.  All the players together in every bite.  Some of the entrees sounded interesting.Misses:  It got really busy for lunch and the bartender was working the bar and the bar area so in fairness -- he was way too busy to provide top service.  Mgmt could add another bar tender or server....because the lady next to me got my pizza but I asked her if she ordered a margarita (she hadn't) so before she took a bite, we switched.  She had ordered the bianca.  ... I wasn't offered any bread and by the time I realized it, the bartender was way too busy to slow down. I am glad I checked it out and will maybe be back (I am averse to paying for parking :)  Comp valet - sure.  Metered parking...not so much especially with it being close to the Fox and on show nights...$20...regular price $5).  But there are some other Italian restaurants I want to try and Cibo e Beve is still my fav (and they offer cooking demos!)

Reviews.Author: Jim W.
Reviews.Content: We had just finished a morning tour of the Fox Theater and were checking out dining options en route back to the parking lot.  This place was on the way and looked promising so we stopped in for lunch.They were not that crowded so we were seated right away.  Our server was initially very attentive but got harder to attract later in the meal.  My wife and I split a basic pizza, which was good.  Our daughter had a pasta dish which she liked.  The wine list seemed quite good, and the selection I got was nice.In all, I might visit again if I were in the area, but I don't think I'd make a special trip from OTP just to dine there again.  If you are attending an event at the Fox, this might be a good dining option.

Reviews.Author: Tiffany D.
Reviews.Content: I like it. I kind of have to. This place is like that best friend you grew up with and love, and although you have had your disagreements, you know you can always go back to them.I have been going to Baraonda for years, and although they tout their fresh pizzas, I highly recommend their pasta entrees. I have had a mushroom tortellini here that was outstanding, with fresh mussels, and a lovely white wine.This place is down the block from the Fox theatre and in the middle of everything, literally. I like to sit on the heated patio in the Fall and people watch. Service can be flighty, depending on the night.This place can get jammed packed on a weekend due to it's location. I recommend calling ahead, they take reservations. Also, parking is tough. Take a cab or park in a garage.The crowd could be a little hipster-y. Everyone kind of wearing the same thing, flipping their hair about. But I don't really mind. I love Atlanta and it's inhabitants.Wear: A well fitting blazer and a cute dress.  Recommended for: Date Night

Reviews.Author: Anthony K.
Reviews.Content: Excellent wood fired pizza. The special was good as well. Thought the wine list could have been a little larger.

Reviews.Author: Michele S.
Reviews.Content: Traveling with a group of colleagues for work, and we decided to stop here for dinner one night.  What a beautiful restaurant, and fantastic wine selection.  I went with a glass of chianti which was worth every penny my company paid for it.  We ordered bruchetta for an appetizer.  The tomatoes were bursting with flavor.  I was so impressed, but maybe the produce in the southern states is better. For dinner, I went with the chicken and spinach ravioli in cream sauce special.  Maybe I was really hungry, but this dish incredible.  The portion was big, but not too big for me to finish the whole thing.  The cream sauce was delicate, and gave a well rounded creamy flavor to the ravioli.  I wish my husband had been with me because he would have loved the menu.  If we ever find ourselves in Atlanta, I'll be sure to take him here for dinner.

Reviews.Author: Sol A.
Reviews.Content: I came here with my team from work. They gave us a big table right away as well as water. The service was quite remarkable with the waiter making good suggestions. We were a big group, so we had a couple of entrees: brocheta, carpaccio, tomato/mozarella and calamari (I only tried the veggie entrees) and they were all good and fresh. For the second entree I decided to have pasta with tomatoes and mozzarella (penne checa?) and it was so fresh and tasty. And, if it wasn't enough after a good pasta and wine, dessert came in! omg! the tiramisu is to die for!

Reviews.Author: Kevin D.
Reviews.Content: I had really high hopes for this place but I stopped in for a drink while I waited for friends to see a show at The Fox and the two bartenders acted like I wasn't even there. I ordered a bourbon on the rocks and it took 10 minutes to get to me. The whole time they were chatting with all the couples around me so I assume it was because I was alone that I ranked so low. Needless to say, my friends and I won't go back there after the show.

Reviews.Author: Ashley M.
Reviews.Content: I was really excited to try this place after hearing some of my friends were big fans! We decided to come here for girls' night, just the four of us. We split a bottle of wine, two pizzas-- a Margherita + shrimp (yum!!!) and the Prosciutto di Parma.  I tried their special for the evening, the braised beef ravioli.My favorite part of the meal was the shrimp pizza. It's not the best pizza EVER, but it was pretty good. I disliked the ravioli because the dish because the sauce was oddly cold.Contrary to some of the other reviews, our table received excellent service from a very friendly older gentleman. I wouldn't mind coming back and sampling one of their more popular dishes from the menu, perhaps I would like it more than my ravioli special. My one big gripe is I think this place is a bit pricey for the value, even for Midtown.

Reviews.Author: Candace M.
Reviews.Content: It really is the best idea to make a reservation if you are planning to eat here.  If you don't check that there is not a show happening at the Fox that night or there will be a wait. Baraonda was OK.  I got the Linguine Pescatore  which was made with shrimp, clams, calamari, white wine, garlic, red chili flakes, Italian cherry tomatoes.  It was ok but I did not like some of the calamari pieces and the seafood in it wasn't that fresh although the overall flavor of the dish was good. What stood out was the calamari, which  were not as tender or fresh as I like them. Other than that, I think that the dish was good.  I loved the Margherita pizza.  My sister got that and I must admit I was a little jealous as I ate my chewy calamari and she chomped down on that fresh tasting pizza.  I was not overly impressed by this place.  It was just nice but I can't really say that I can go on and on about how great the food was.  I will say that this is a good little spot to stop by if you are planning to see a show at the Fox.  Over all experience, with the restaurant and a show will make it a good night.  Enjoy!!

Reviews.Author: R B.
Reviews.Content: The venue is gorgeous!!!Food is delicious!

Reviews.Author: Tracy A.
Reviews.Content: Had dinner here before a show at the Fox.  Had the Pollo Picatta, which was delicious.  My friends and family all enjoyed what they ordered as well.  The room we were in was a bit loud, hard to hear at times, but there was some lovely outdoor seating.....

Reviews.Author: Ange T.
Reviews.Content: We stopped in after a Georgia Tech football game. Our team lost, but my meal at Baronda was a winner. I really enjoyed my pizza, the sauce tasted very fresh. For once, I cannot complain about the service; our waitress was great, as a matter of fact, everyone on staff that afternoon seemed very nice and friendly.

Reviews.Author: Robert M.
Reviews.Content: Margarita review:Baraonda used to be a regular haunt for me, what a great place for a quick meal.  A few weeks ago I got back to Baraonda for the first time in a long time, and quickly remembered why it was a regular haunt.This is one of the best pies in Atlanta, brick oven style.  Beautiful thin, charred crust with a smoke infused flavor, fresh ingredients and taste, good amount of sauce with the right cheese ratio.  Just as surprising though, is that their pasta was very good.  I was never big on Baraonda's pasta but it clearly improved.  Would I choose it over their za though?  No way...

Reviews.Author: Rick F.
Reviews.Content: Light Bite after the show at the Fox Theatre.Caprese Salad was excellent just the right amount of fresh basil and Olive Oil.Spicy Salami and prosciutto de Parma and Arugula Pizza was above average.Service was great, friendly and entertaining!

Reviews.Author: Joel C.
Reviews.Content: Leslie, Robert and I were heading to the Atlanta Pride Parade and got off at the North Ave exit.  As we approached Peachtree Street we ran into a bunch of our neighborhood friends.  Then without warning, it started to pour.  We ran into Baraonda and to our surprise, they were able to sit us at a window table facing Peachtree Street!We started with the fried calamari, which was delicious.  Leslie and I ordered pizzas and Robert ordered a pasta dish.  I really enjoyed Robert's pasta dish more than my pizza (well actually Leslie enjoyed it more by practically eating the entire thing!), but the pizza was very good.  The parade started and we had the perfect view!  I totally felt like VIP at this years pride parade and may have to think about doing this again next year if it starts to rain as hard as it did today!

Reviews.Author: Sabrina C.
Reviews.Content: This is generally my go-to location when I'm in this part of town and on the way to the fox/other show.  The food is quite tasty, the service is a little snooty and overall the prices are somewhat high...In all its worth a go...

Reviews.Author: Katie W.
Reviews.Content: I've always enjoyed the pizza at Baraonda but had not written a review since it had been a while since I'd actually been there.  Then, last week, I had the good fortune of eating at Baraonda twice in a single week!  And, it was very good fortune because I do love Baraonda.I mainly stick to the pizzas here because I really cannot miss with them.  I've never had a bad pizza here.  In fact, I've never had one that was less than delicious.  I used to always stick to the Quattro Formaggi with added arugula but I branched out this week to try the Capricciosa and the Specialita (with added gorgonzola).  Both were excellent.  I love the thin crust, the char on the pizza and the foldability.  And, the ingredients are very fresh and flavorful, too.I also had the fried calamari this week and tried Kit's special risotto.  The risotto was delicious and it makes me think that I should consider the specials and the pastas when I eat here in the future (although it will sure be tough to sway me from the pizza).  In the past, I have had salads here, as well, which were very good.The service was overall very good, the wine list has a nice selection of wine by the glass as well as full bottles, and we received our food very promptly.  I do like the décor and I think it is fun to eat here.  It's also kinda fun to sit at the back bar where you can watch them making the pizzas (although it can get a little warm - sit here in cold weather, not summer).  I also hear that they only take reservations for parties of six or more.I am so happy my memories of Baraonda were so pleasantly refreshed.  I will definitely be back soon!

Reviews.Author: Danilo G.
Reviews.Content: I get to Atlanta quite a bit.  This place hit my radar a few months back when I started staying at the Indigo.  I went in on MLK day for an early cocktail, and found their selection of bourbons very good, and resolved to give them a shot over a corporate meal soon after.Baraonda gets grief for not being too regional.  I think that's fabulous, since there are so many specialty dishes from so many regions, Baraonda can't be pigeonholed.Two days later myself and three compadres walked through the front door with a big appetite.  We had appetizers:CarpaccioCapreseBruschettaBourbons all around.Dinner:Strozzapreti with Wild BoarVeal ScallopiniLamb ChopsBig bottle of Italian RedDessert involved Strega and Limoncello with Tiramisu.Oh my God was the service and food fantastic.  Our host, Adriano, made damned sure that our waitstaff and food was top notch, recommending some fabulous stuff and keeping us laughing so hard we were hoarse the next day.  Everything was amazing and the entire evening was so wonderful I can't wait to go back.The Wild Boar, Lamb Chops and Carpaccio stood out.  The Carpaccio was cut so thin you could read a newspaper, but yet the portion was plentiful.  The Lamb Chops, which can be a "phone in", were anything but.  Beautifully herby, well-presented and completely off the ubiquitous scale, I haven't had anything like them and I've eaten enough Lamb to cause a panic in New Zealand.And then there was the Strozzaprete with Wild Boar Ragu -- What a perfect mix.  Strozzaprete means "Priest Strangler".  It is long and curvaceously U-shaped, and perfect for Ragu, or meat sauce.  The Wild Boar is a traditional dish from the Marche' region of Italy (think east coast, mid-way down the Adriatic).  I cannot say enough about this dish.  We had two orders, and when I took a bite I was utterly speechless. As I write this I'm trying to recreate it in my kitchen.  It will take me weeks and hundreds of dollars to get it right.  To hell with it.  I'm getting a plane ticket and going back.  Don't go in a hurry -- I think that a lot of people try to catch a quick bite on the way to the theatre.  This is Italian food.  It should and will take hours if you want your money's worth.If you want Italian in Atlanta, I don't think you could do better.  Make friends with Adriano and you'll never be sorry.

Reviews.Author: Sandra K.
Reviews.Content: DISCLAIMER:  I've never eaten here.  I've only had some beers.  Yet they quickly accommodated a group of fifteen, so I liked them already.So why am I writing this review?  Because I saw a bartender at this place, who will go unnamed, make sure that a damsel in distress made it back to her hotel up the block safe and sound.  I exited the bathroom and saw the server (going off shift) offering to help the girl who was completely incoherent.  To make things not-sketchy, he turned to me and asked if I would help him escort her two blocks away so that she could get home safely.  I didn't know him, I didn't know her, but I was happy to help someone out.  This man is a hero.  And now I have a friend for life.If the rest of the staff has a heart like this guy, then five stars all around for Baraonda.

Reviews.Author: Paolo B.
Reviews.Content: I'm from Italy and whenever i want to eat real Italian food, i chose Baraonda! The owner is Italian, the food is really good and not expensive. The wine is also good, you can find a lot of types of wine from all over the Italy.  The restaurant is nice, just a little bit small.. but if your party is with 6+ people, you can book a table.If you like Italian food, you may love Baraonda!

Reviews.Author: Drew W.
Reviews.Content: I usually keep my Italian/pizza outings low-key, but I decided to give Baraonda a try before a show at the Fox. I've had some less than stellar experiences at "gourmet" pizza establishments (yes, I'm looking right at you Piebar). Baraonda was a nice change that shows that you can use better ingredients, charge a little more for it, but not take yourself so seriously (ahem, Piebar) to be obnoxious.In the evening you get a nice mix of after work midtowners and ITP'ers venturing into the scary city to see a show or meet friends. Baraonda has a nice selection of affordable wines, and they are frequently having specials. Most importantly, the bartenders aren't afraid to use a heavy hand when you order bourbon. Or maybe I just look like the type that needs a lot of bourbon.I can't remember the specific name of the pizza that I tried on my last visit, but it had some peppery arugula and lots of slices of prosciutto on top. Pizza with cured meats? I could eat that every day until my heart explodes. Which should happen just about....

Reviews.Author: Randy G.
Reviews.Content: Every time I come here I say, why don't I come here more often? I really should as I live just blocks away and walk by it often.I have never had a bad meal here. Maybe it isn't the most amazing but it is always really good and at a reasonable price. And I always drink a glass or four of some interesting Italian wine and leave happy!The decor is nice and relaxing. The aroma of the pizzas fills the air nicely. I usually order one of the specials if it sounds intriguing. Otherwise I will order the Linguine Pescatore. Service is good, especially when I sit at the bar. Had a great conversation with the bartender last night.   A real enjoyable evening. Good food, good wine, good service.Yay! I'm a fan.

Reviews.Author: Amanda S.
Reviews.Content: You know what I love about Yelp?  The fact that, when you're in a restaurant, they don't know you're going to yelp about it, so they treat you like anyone else.  And when my boyfriend and I came here for a nice dinner last night, we certainly didn't receive any special treatment.I made sure to check showtimes for the nearby Fox, and there wasn't a show until 8pm.  We arrived at about 5:15, and waited for about 20 minutes for a table for two.We were seated in the back corner, right next to the pizza oven.  The smells were fantastic.A guy (not our waiter) promptly came over and filled our water glasses.  It wasn't until about 10 minutes later that our waitress showed up.  When she asked for our drink order, I said, "I'll just have water, thanks."The waitress looked at me as if I were a moron.  "Okay, your water's right there."  She pointed at the glass of water that I had already drank from as if trying to communicate with a chimp.Can you tell I was offended?She then said, "Do you guys want to order now, or what?"  So we ordered, having looked at the menu while waiting for a table, and she rushed off.Every 5-10 minutes, the little guy would return to refill our water glasses, but the waitress only showed up whenever I made eye contact with her when she was at another table.  It was pathetic.  I mean, I can understand her being busy, but it was simply ridiculous...and rude, to say the very least.Our food was brought out by someone other than our waitress.  Brad & I split a pizza and a bowl of pasta.We ordered the Penne Sausicia, a penne dish with crumbled sausage in a white cream sauce.  It was wonderful.  The pasta was perfectly al dente, and the sauce and sausage was an intriguing combo.Our pizza was the Funghi Pizza, meaning that it was just topped with mushrooms.  The mushrooms were fresh and thinly sliced.  The crust was thin and flakey.  It was good, but not fantastic.Meanwhile, some elderly people were seated beside us as we ate.  Their party was being split in two because there wasn't room to seat a party of 6 on a Friday night without a reservation, which wasn't clearly expressed to them before the 6 of them were escorted to a tiny 4-seat table.  They looked baffled.Once they (or at least, half of them) were situated, the waitress (our waitress) came over to them.  She introduced herself as Sonya (the first, and only, time all night that I'd heard her name) and told them about all of the specials they were having.Specials?  I didn't even know they HAD specials.  Thanks, Sonya.  Really.  You're a doll.So yeah...I'd say 4 stars for the food.  The pasta and pizza are both authentic Italian.  But 1 star for the service, and only because of the prompt little guy refilling my water glass.  Sonya gets 0 stars for making me feel completely insignificant.EDIT: Forgot to mention this.  As we were leaving, we heard a guy complaining to the hostess, "You said it'd be 20 minutes.  Twenty minutes does not take over an hour!"

Reviews.Author: Courtney N.
Reviews.Content: I feel like they kind of don't deserve the title of being an Italian place since 70% of the entree options are pizza or calzones (there are like 4 pasta options and 3-4 secondi options).  With that in mind, it was absolutely delicious and they were VERY accomodating.  Here's what we ordered:Free bread -  Great flavor from seasonings on top, crusty foccacia styleCalamari  - Light breading, crisp, not greasy, lacked seasoningVeal Scallopine Marsala - Breading was a little mushy but overall it was delicious.  The marsala sauce is to die for and the mushrooms were perfectly sauteed.Chicken Piccata (NOT ON THE MENU) - They made this for us by special request because they happened to have a salmon piccata as a special for the day.  For just throwing something together, this was delicious. Bottle of Sartori Pinot GrigioI would definitely go back next time I am in Atlanta.  The decor is fantastic and inviting. Dark woods, spacious seating, dim lighting but not in a way that is too intensely romantic that you would feel awkward going with friends or a group.If they added 2 or 3 more pasta dishes to the menu, it would definitely bump them up to 5 stars in my book :)

Reviews.Author: duane m.
Reviews.Content: Now, I'm gonna start with this: I ain't one to pay high prices for a dinner, but I have to say, this place was more than meets the eye. While my meal was more than I would normally rather fork out, I managed to have a few beers, and a delicious pizza for about $25. I went for a friend's birthday celebration, and was pleased to see us seated with reserved tables for our party. The service wasn't stellar, but it wasn't bad either; she split the check for me, and totally improvised with the pizza requests I had.Now, I don't think that this will be a place I chose frequently, but if people suggest that we go here, I will be all about it; I had a great meal, a great time, and look forward to similar experiences in the future.

Reviews.Author: Anelya S.
Reviews.Content: I was visiting Atlanta, and had lunch at this restaurant with good friend of mine, and I loved my garlic and cherry tomato linguinie and he was pretty happy about his spinach ravioli. The one thing we noticed was service. During our conversation small accident happened and glass of water spilled on the table. Waiter was right next to us, he saw it smiled and left. Never got back, we wiped everything out with napkins. Then manager came by just to pick up tab, and "managed" not to notice wet pile of napkins on our table. Overall food is good and not that pricey, but I won't be back.

Reviews.Author: Yvette J.
Reviews.Content: I have to agree with Karen F. - best risotto ever!The only downfall was when my husband ordered a bourbon and coke. Our very Italian waiter brought him a coke and a bourbon - in separate glasses.

Reviews.Author: Matt Y.
Reviews.Content: Alright, let's start with the good stuff.The food,every time I've been here, has been excellent. Well, on my last visit the ravioli was a bit too al dente, but it wasn't worth complaining about at the time because it was still quite tasty.The price, well, it's a bit more on the expensive side I would say. Don't come here if you're trying to be frugal but it's not prohibitively expensive.My one complaint, no iced tea. What continent are they living on? Atlanta  is hades hot in the summer, even at night and they can't get the proper equipment to brew some freaking tea? FAIL. If I were paying in Euros and not using deodorant then I'd expect them not to have iced tea, simply because the concept of ice has yet to hit the Europen mindset, and that's fine, for them. However, they have ice in the water and they can go through the trouble of having a full bar so go brew some iced tea already. For this huge oversight, they have achieved an epic fail, so three stars is the best I can give them.

Reviews.Author: Kristine M.
Reviews.Content: I have yet to have a real complaint about Baraonda, after several visits and several delivery orders through Zifty.  Whenever I'm actually in, I've already eaten or the ravioli du jour is lobster (nrom nrom nrom), so I've gotten that.  When I get delivery, it's usually pizza, which is good, but not nearly as good-looking as when it's pulled fresh out of the brick oven and piping hot.Decent wine selection, good service.  Ok but not write-home-about-it decor.  I'd take family or friends that were in town.  Not sure I'd bring a must-impress date or business colleague.  (Yet.  This could change.)

Reviews.Author: Loren S.
Reviews.Content: I visited Baraonda for the first time last night, and boy was I impressed!  The restaurant does not look especially big or impressive from the outside, but the layout and decor definitely delivered.  The tables are great for intimate meals with friends, the hip layout is at the same time alluring and relaxing.  While there were families at a number of tables, I wouldn't generally think of Baraonda as a family restaurant.  If you don't have time for a full meal, but still want to soak up the amazing atmosphere, they have a full bar and an extensive wine list.The menu is long and there were numerous specials last night, but we were all about the pizza.  I recommend the 'Specialita', with an addition of spicy salami.  This harmony of wood-fired flavors is amazing: cherry tomatoes, mozzarella, arugula, goat cheese and the aforementioned salami on a thin, crispy crust provide a fresh, slightly salty combination that is beyond delightful.At just $12, this pizza for two will not break the bank.Others have described this restaurant as great for people-watching, or a great dining location for a night out at the Fox Theater, but give Baraonda its due: this restaurant is just plain great.

Reviews.Author: James U.
Reviews.Content: Baraonda is one of the best Italian places in Atlanta (and ATL is BIG!).  I hate parking myself, hate being in a downtown area, and /hate/ crowds.  But I will gladly put up with all three to eat here.  The pizza and pasta are always good, and the waiters actually seem to know which wines will taste good with which meal (maybe they have a cheat sheet?).Now that we have moved away I find myself missing the good eats there.  This is definitely on the 'Tour of Atlanta' I plan to take when I finally get to go back for a visit.

Reviews.Author: Henrik C.
Reviews.Content: The restaurant has both an patio/"outside" area and a regular indoor area. The indoor area is a joint bar/restaurant. The outside area is on the sidewalk and you might have exhaust as an integral part of your dinner. Some might like that, personally I prefer dinner without exhaust. The restaurant/bar area is rather noisy and can be rather busy. The food is traditional Italian with a good variety of antipasto, pizza and a variety of pasta. The menu is limited but overall the food is fantastic. We have tried ravioli, lasagna, and pesce giorno. All of the dishes were really great. They have a Monday night wine taster. Stay away from it, the price is good but the wines are not. Other than that they have really good Italian wines. If you do not mind the noisy ambiance or sitting on the sidewalk this is a great place to get Italian food.

Reviews.Author: Sona C.
Reviews.Content: Came here to celebrate my 25th bday. We had pastas, which were average. Some of the customers were snobbish. Was sort of expensive, this place will fall in the $$$ price range. Our server though was a nice lady- she brought my purse out which I had forgotten inside.

Reviews.Author: Amber M.
Reviews.Content: Took my sister here for pre-Nutcracker afternoon show at the Fox. At first it looked like a chain restaurant but once we settled into two seats at the bar it started to grow on me. Odd music but fabulous place to split a pizza and a salad. Everything was very fresh, cold when it should be cold, hot when it should be hot. Moretti on tap, skip the bloody mary.Big windows to watch people freezing their behinds off, pushing through a windy day. I'll definitely go back for the pizza on another day, no show at the Fox required.

Reviews.Author: Jesse W.
Reviews.Content: So we popped into Baraonda after sneaking out of a horrible presentation of Grease at the Fox. After such disappointment at the theater, we were really hoping to turn around the evening with some good food. We weren't disappointed.We started with a Caprese salad that was a great way to start the meal. For my main dish I ordered a wood-fired pizza since that seemed to be what many other folks were ordering.  Not sure the name of the pizza but it had broccoli, zucchini, onions, roasted red peppers, and very little cheese (if any). The crust was thin and crispy, and the toppings were light a very tasty. It certainly wasn't the kind of pizza that I would go back to if I had a real hankering for pizza, but as an off-the-beaten-path kind of pizza, I couldn't have been happier.Service was good, the place was maybe a little loud, but other than that, it was a solid dining experience.

Reviews.Author: Steven B.
Reviews.Content: I called... I was sent to a computer. I went to the front door. Locked. No note on the door, No outgoing message.. Did this place close? The stars don't matter since I love the pizza there normally and it's very close to me. But restaurants come and go so fast in Midtown without notice I wouldn't be surprised if it was gone too. At best they decided to close on Easter Sunday and failed to let potential diners know the situation. Poor customer relations. At worst they locked the doors and sent the employees home for unemployment. I hope they at least got a bottle of wine.

Reviews.Author: Jeremy A.
Reviews.Content: I would come back here for sure based on my one visit. I had a italian sausage penne dish and it was very good. My girlfriend had the tagliatelle and it was pretty good as well. I can see parking being a huge pain in the ass here so try to go during the week or park down the street.

Reviews.Author: Jai R.
Reviews.Content: Creepy ass waiter and disappointing food.I tried the Romana pizza with is Italian bacon, sauteed onions, mozzarella and sun dried tomatoes.  It was bland and nothing worth a further discussion.  My friend had the seafood linguine.  He said it taste like the noodles were smothered in flames then boiled in hotdog water.  But on a brighter not the wine list is good and I had a wonderful pinot noir.

Reviews.Author: Julia B.
Reviews.Content: Go see my buddy Spencer the bartender.  He is hilarious.  A few glasses of big, bold, red wine and a thin crust pizza split between myself and Spencer's wife along with some fabulously fresh salad made for a terrific evening at Baraonda.It goes without saying that this and Bazaar are some of your best pre- and post-Fox Theatre outings.  But Baraonda is worth the trip for any old day as well.  It has consistently served delicious food, atmosphere and wine every time I have paid a visit.

Reviews.Author: Liz C.
Reviews.Content: If one of my BFFs didn't like this place more than breathing (okay, maybe not that much, but pretty close), I might have never tried Baraonda. And what a shame that would be!On a recent dinner visit to Baraonda with the aforementioned BFF and her mom, I tried the Anatra pizza. I swapped the sundried tomatoes for mushrooms, which were delicious. But the true highlight of this dish was the duck breast. I'm a duck fanatic, and this did not disappoint. I was stuffed to the gills from gorging myself on my duck pizza, so I didn't have any dessert on this visit, but I've had their tiramisu before and I can safely say that it's one of the best I've ever had anywhere. They also serve up a tasty and rich cup of java.I think the service here is good and the atmosphere is relaxing. It's a great spot for a date or dining with friends and it's proximity to the always awesome Fox Theatre makes it a great pre-show spot.

Reviews.Author: Todd P.
Reviews.Content: Business lunch meetings are great for several reasons. 1) It's lunch! 2) It's paid for by the company. Yeehaw!My most recent venue for tasty food and a little bit of shop talk: Baraonda. I've been meaning to try this place for some time and was glad I got the chance. Hopefully I can make it back again soon since this first visit made me smile.I ordered their daily fish special, a grilled tuna steak served with a generous pile of steamed spinach and a slice of tomato dressed in olive oil. Simple, perfectly cooked, delicious. And healthy!

Reviews.Author: Kaitlin L.
Reviews.Content: In the spirit of seeing Mamma Mia - we thought we would do a nice Italian meal before hand.  Being a Saturday night - we got there around 6pm and waited about 30 minutes for a table.Everything was just OK.  Service was good - but impersonal and I felt like we were being rushed through.  Food was good - but small portions.  I even asked the waiter when I ordered their special lobster ravioli - is this going to be a tiny portion?  No - its entree size.  Yes the plate may have been entree size - but there were 5 pieces!  So I probably wouldn't go back - but I wouldn't steer people away - it was exactly how I expected it to be after reading all the reviews.

Reviews.Author: Patrick C.
Reviews.Content: Baraonda is the perfect place to eat before a Fox Theatre event. Our party of six dined there prior to Wicked (which is another review altogether.)Reservations for larger parties are tricky, and Baraonda didn't make the grade. Unfortunately, one in our party is diabetic and must eat on a rigid schedule. Let's just say she didn't have a good evening.Reservations aside, my eating partner and I split the calamari (which was somewhat rubbery, had little flavor and possibly was a frozen product) and a Margherita-pizza-add-Italian-sausage. The pizza wasn't as good as we had remembered from a previous visit, and the quality of the Italian sausage wasn't acceptable. A nice bottle of Italian wine helped matters along, but wine does not a meal make. (Well, I suppose that's debatable...)In fairness, this place was packed, so they're doing something right. I try not to judge too harshly the *potential* of a restaurant when it is at full capacity. Seventy percent capacity is best - it keeps the food turned over and fresh, keeps everyone on her/his toes but doesn't make the staff crazy. This staff tried to overcome the craziness, but insanity is contagious, yes? The management needs to rethink some things or they will kill the goose that laid the golden egg.Not recommended prior to Fox events; however, we'll return when it's not so bizzycrazy.

Reviews.Author: Courtney C.
Reviews.Content: For always being so crowded after shows at the Fox, I thought Baraonda was going to be "fa bene" fantastic. Well, the shirts the waiters wear certainly are adorable, but the food was just "A-OK." Our waiter was lively, and the wine was good (not sure what we had though), but the carpaccio was under-seasoned, the calamari was under-seasoned and a bit greasy (but not rubbery at all and not over-breaded so that's good), and the bruchetta bread wasn't as crunchy as I like it (but the tomatoes were good and fresh and plenty garlicky). As for the entrees, two people at the table had to send the halibut special back because it was dry. My pizza (the romana) was dry. Another tablemate's pizza was...you guessed it, dry! The lobster risotto was very tasty and full of lobster, so that was definitely the winner. I'd say that this place needs to revamp itself or risk losing business, but its premiere location next to the Fox Theater makes me certain it'll maintain its flow. If I return I'll try their risotto of the day or maybe a pasta. And I'll definitely try to buy one of their adorable t-shirts!

Reviews.Author: Mike D.
Reviews.Content: I'm an Italian from the North East and this is the only Italian restaurant in Atlanta that I will go to. The food in Italy is prepared with simple ingredients. The reviewers saying it taste bland might just be to used to the Olive Garden to enjoy this place.I've been several times and have always enjoyed the food. I have had several dishes specially prepared that are not on the menu, that were very good as well.I took a date here one time and one of the waiters sung at our table in Italian. It doesn't get any more romantic than that! This is where the Italians in Atlanta go...nuff said.

Reviews.Author: J. D.
Reviews.Content: Still a quality classic and is more "under the radar" than it should be. A recent pleasurable experience: my girl friend is a vegetarian and they created an off the menu veggie plate to rival any in the city. i'm still not sure what they did to the zucchini to make it taste so good. My evening special of Brasstown beef ribeye was also better than any steak I've had in Atlanta.Yes, I ate meat in front of the girl - she is okay with it!  Keep up the good work guys.

Reviews.Author: Steve B.
Reviews.Content: Located at Peachtree Street and 3rd in Atlanta, Baraonda is an Italian restaurant that has some nice touches.  The ambiance is pleasant, the wait staff is nice and its location - one block north of the Fox Theatre - is great.Recently, 7 of us met for dinner and ordered 7 different dishes from the menu.  There is nothing wrong with the food but, ostensibly, Baraonda is billed as a notch above the crowd - the reason we went there.  In the opinion of our group, it really isn't.  I'm not knocking Baraonda but, at this price point you'll need a reason to select this restaurant above others in the general area - perhaps, a show at the Fox or a business client staying in a close hotel - or, you live in Midtown.If you go to Baraonda, there is parking across Peachtree St. behind the Bank of America building on 3rd.  It was easy to park and a quick walk up 3rd delivers you to the front door.Bottom line:  I have all intentions of giving Baraonda a second shot - then updating this post.  I'd say try it for yourself, you may love it.

Reviews.Author: Carrie Neal W.
Reviews.Content: Yesterday, I wanted to want my usual beloved checca. But . . .it just wasn't quiiite what sounded perfect. So after a bit of menu-perusing, I went for the calamari (and decided I could always get the pasta to-go, and have it for dinner!).For $7, a huge plate. Even better, it was delicious - all "rings" (the tentacly pieces creep me out), lightly fried just so, and with a yummy marinara sauce and fresh lemon wedges for squeezing over the dish.Exactly what I wanted, as it turned out - and certainly something I'll order again!

Reviews.Author: Debbie K.
Reviews.Content: Food: The pizzas are nice and thin & crusty.  The cheese tortellini was delicious and the halibut special was nicely prepared.  Some of the dishes seem to be a bit heavy handed on the salt.  The calamari starter in particular was quite salty, as were the sides that came with the halibut.  Liked the wine choices.Service:  It was uneven.  This last time, the hostess seemed distracted and the bartender (we got drinks while we waited for our table) wasn't very nice.  We liked our waiter though he forgot one of our drink orders until we reminded him. Overall: Easy, low-key place for Italian food. Good place to get a bunch of friends together and start the night off .

Reviews.Author: Valentina V.
Reviews.Content: Baraonda is always my spot for pre or post Fox visits, and if you have a soft spot for good looking waiters, this is your place! When I visit before the shows I usually have drinks. Their flavored Martinis are good, and the Brandy Alexander is great. Wine list is pretty decent, too. Usually is a good time to hit this spot because is not as packed as the apres show time. Oh, and after a blissfully happy night at the Fox (I've been blessed with just gooood shows at my favorite theater of all times) then it's dinner time! Baraonda is a must for this plan always. But listen (or read) very carefully: this restaurant has good pizza, really, really good pizza. DON'T even look at the pastas. The one time I had pasta I was extremely disappointed. Salty penne with "italian sausage" that I could barely eat.  My fave pizza is the Cafuncella, a delicious blend of prosciutto and brie cooked to perfection in their brick oven. To be fair, I often order the Cozze (mussels in white wine and garlic sauce) and I have to say, it is lush and mmmmmm!Expect a loud, and crowded place after 7:30 PM. That means a fairly long wait. Reservations are not especially honored, but yes, the hostesses are nice girls. And it's definitely a spot to go see and be seen.

Reviews.Author: Liz L.
Reviews.Content: Even though we had one of the worst waiters known to man at this place, I'll still give it four stars.  And I'll still tip nearly 20%.  Because people have bad days, and I can acknowledge that with the best of them. So.  On to the food.  And the divine prices.  Calamari.  Excellent.  Pizza.  Suburb (and by "suburb" I'm pretty sure I meant "superb").  Salad.  Pretty good, but I'd ask for the dressing on the side, especially when ordering the Caesar salad, which apparently was slogged down in liquid to the point of being nearly inedible.  Also kudos to the hostess who gave us a nice warning to come in about 1/2 later than originally planned so as to avoid the Fox Theatre crowd.  I've had too many run-ins on the phone with hostesses of the "I'm-too-busy-to-take-five-second-to-actually-be-­a-human-being-and-talk-to-you-slash-do-my-job" variety, and this was a welcome departure from those.  Plus it's a great location.  Although I'm still not sure what I think about its sister restaurant, Enoteca Carbonari, having a space right next door.  I understand the theory - the lower priced pizza/pasta parlor in an slightly upscale environment, and the more formal Italian restaurant right next door, but it almost seems like over kill to me.  However, I haven't been to Enoteca Carbonari yet, so I suppose I'll have to sacrifice myself for the greater good and go there to eat, and see if it's worth it.Sigh.  I have it so rough...

Reviews.Author: Guru P.
Reviews.Content: This is one where I wish we could give stars in 1/2s....  The food was good but the seating was highly uncomfortable.  The service was below par.  The waiter took 10 mins to get my son's soda.  This at the time the place was half empty (the show was about to start!!).  So, I wish I could give them 3.5 stars!The pizzas were good as expected.  The drinks are decent.  So, all in all a good place for a casual dinner.

Reviews.Author: Scott C.
Reviews.Content: Really wasn't impressed with Baraonda.  I was there with friends after a Fox event this week.  They were quite busy for 930 pm.  The service was just adequate.  Our server was very soft spoken in a loud restaurant.  I kept having to ask him to repeat himself.  His accent didnt help, but I can live with that.  Either turn down the music or turn up the voice.  Decor was fine, but I see those same posters in Target and TJ Maxx.Food was not flavorful and was a little on the high side.  $19 for a pizza, diet Coke and tip is ridiculous.   A few sun dried tomatoes, Italian bacon, grilled onions, cheese and crust.  Flavor was lacking and the oven had some hot spots on the bottom of the crust.  I would have been happier at Slice, Oz, Johnnies or Felinis.

Reviews.Author: Gale E.
Reviews.Content: I work in Midtown and spend a lot of time there in various restaurants, and I want to like this one.  The octopus and pizzas are good, but the host, bartender and servers are not service-oriented.  In other words, pretentious and not particularly warm.  I'll go to Lure where I can sit at the bar and be greeted as a friend.

Reviews.Author: Simon C.
Reviews.Content: I can realistically say I have never had a bad meal at Baraonda. The setting is laid back and romantic enough for a date but also great for a professional lunch or other engagements. The food is always good, most especially their Prosciutto de Parma pizza which I find myself in withdrawals from occasionally. The pastas are all good from what I hear (I stick to the aforementioned pizza) and the appetizers are fantastic. A good and moderately priced wine list makes this a favorite as well.All in all I would say this is by far my favorite Italian restaurant in Atlanta and competes for the number 1 spot over all. Check it out.

Reviews.Author: chelsa v.
Reviews.Content: Had a late Monday evening dinner here with a girlfriend of mine,  awesome night to sit outside enjoy the weather over a nice glass of red wine and good company.  The pasta dish I ordered was good.  The red wine was nice and spicy, just as I requested.Our waiter,  with his cute accent, made ordering fun!The patio had the perfect ambiance.Great hours to accommodate for last minute plans. Close to my house. Good enough for 5 stars, if you ask me.

Reviews.Author: Emily K.
Reviews.Content: I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with Baraonda. The food is good, but the wait can be agonizing if you go at the wrong time. The restaurant is fairly small, so it can take a while to get a table. I'm one of those people that hates eating "outside". Why do I want to stare at a parked car while I'm eating? However, I'll suck it up because often the outdoor tables free up more quickly than ones indoors.The staff is friendly and knowledgable. It's not too loud in spite of the fact it's fairly small. The menu isn't huge, but that means that the kitchen can master them rather than be only okay at a wider variety of dishes.I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, but if I'm in the area and in the mood to wait a bit, I'd stop in and get a bite.

Reviews.Author: Rachel P.
Reviews.Content: Clearly this restaurant's life is maintained by its proximity to the Fabulous Fox Theater, because other restaurants with much better food and service have not made it in this town. Our service was friendly but forgetful...we never got out wine at all.  The food was variable but mostly intensely mediocre, almost flavorless.  All this AND an upscale price.Walk three blocks further and have a really nice meal at ECCO, who has remained open due to great food, ambience, and service if you want a restaurant at that price in this neighborhood.

Reviews.Author: Mark B.
Reviews.Content: Wow. We had the rudest service of our lives here. But a pretty good pizza. In fact, the pizza rates five stars simply because it is Atlanta's best. Thin crust, charred, with excellent toppings. Priced right, all very European.But Craig, oh my, what an unbelievable attitude. He tried to explain it later by saying most people were trying to get to a show at the fox and therefore wanted to be out really quick. Like being waited on by a stormtrooper.Come here for the pizza and Europeeish charm but do request someone other than Craig!

Reviews.Author: Christopher H.
Reviews.Content: My theater buddy and I had wanted to try Baraonda for a long time, so we had dinner there before catching a show at the Fox.  We arrived around 6:00, and were seated immediately on the plastic-wrapped patio.  It was a rainy night, but not cold out, so we weren't real sure why all the heaters were on (it was sweltering on the patio).  Our server was friendly and attentive, with the other server on the patio helping out when she wasn't immediately available.  After placing our orders, the food came out fairly quickly.I ordered the vegetarian linguine with red sauce, my "date" had the rigatoni norma.  While I can't say the linguine was awesome, it was tasty and the portion size was excellent.  I ate every bit of it.  My partner seemed to enjoy her rigatoni; there weren't any complaints.When considering everything, including the prices, we decided Baraonda was an OK place, but nowhere near the best Italian available in the city.  As we were leaving, the comment was said we wouldn't be in a hurry to return.Several hours later... my opinion of Baraonda changed from "eh" to "never again".  I can assure you the vegetable linguine tasted much better going down than it did coming up.  Doing a postmortem with my friend, we realized the only thing I ate that she didn't was the veggie linguine.  We both had the same bread, same red sauce on our dishes, same everything other than the linguine. I can't tell you how wonderful it is to puke up a $40 dinner in this economy!

Reviews.Author: Maggie R.
Reviews.Content: I hate to say it, but I wasn't all that impressed with my experience here.The bread was nice, but it wasn't good enough to where I would continue eating it (which turned out to be convenient, since our server was not reliably around that often).  When I'm served bread with olive oil, unless it's a specific olive oil tasting (see: Sotto Sotto), I've come to expect a balsamic vinegar option as well. No such luck here, and the olive oil wasn't special enough to hold its own.My dining partner ordered the Mahi Mahi, which was a special that day, and I ordered the special pizza for that day, which included pesto, chicken, sun-dried tomatoes, and mushrooms. My pizza was a little difficult to maneuver, as all of the toppings kept falling off. I feel as if the mushrooms were a little too prominently featured; they almost became a nuisance, and had there been mozzarella on the pizza, it would have mellowed that flavor enough to where it wouldn't have been overkill... but it was a pizza with no cheese. It was mushroom central, and when the two main features I'm getting off a pizza (pesto and mushroom) don't necessarily complement each other, I get a little worried.The crust was... weird. Definitely "real" Italian crust, for sure, but the type of flour dusting on it was more sour than I was prepared for. I wish there had been a way for it to be sweeter, which I think would have been more suitable for the pizza.The Mahi Mahi was well-prepared, but it was essentially just the fish, with very few spices or seasonings, and it didn't taste fresh enough to where I trusted it to stand on its own. The vegetables that came with it were a little bland.It's totally possible that I was here on an off day in the kitchen, since many of the other reviewers seemed to enjoy their experience a lot. I'd consider going back one more time. The atmosphere was certainly nice, and they validate parking in the Bank of America building, which is a quick walk from the restaurant. When our server was around, he was very nice and very accommodating... he just wasn't around much. Oh well. I'd try it again, but it won't be top priority for me by a long shot.

Reviews.Author: Wendy S.
Reviews.Content: I have eaten at this place a few times in the last year when i visit atlanta.  it happens to be the closest place to grab food near our hotel.  tonight was my first take out experience. i ordered salad + pizza and was told that it would be ready in 10 minutes.  I arrived for my take out in 10 minutes and it was ready.  I picked up my dinner for $19.45.  Now I know why it was ready so quick.  1.  the pizza was not cut, thus i am left here in my hotel to rip it into pieces.  2.  the salad looks good, but just a pile of greens with some shredded carrots.  If you have not other options, then hit this place up.  otherwise, keep looking.

Reviews.Author: Michelle B.
Reviews.Content: Had to update my review...I'm not sure if they've gotten new management, but the food has gone WAY downhill in the last couple of months. Maybe it's just 'cause I get it to go, but STILL...!!!Pizza Margherita is SUPPOSED to be topped with tomatoes, basil and mozzarella. That's what it says on the menu. That's what I got when I had it in Rome, New York, St. Maartin and every place else in Atlanta. That's what they show on their website...several times. That's not what I got here the last couple of trips. All I got was cheese pizza with a couple of basil leaves on top. I can do that at home. To make matters worse, I was told I didn't know what True Margherita pizza was when I called to complain. EXCUSE ME??? I wonder if the person I spoke to on the phone was the same one who told me I couldn't get a job there unless I spoke Spanish? WHATEVER!!!

Reviews.Author: Travis N.
Reviews.Content: I don't know why I always end up at this place in odd hours, (eating lunch at 2pm, eating dinner at 530pm etc).The first time I went I ended up having the Ravioli of the day, which was a little crisp for a pasta dish (either it was sitting out too long, or it was a little stale).The other times I've stuck with their pizza, which are very good.  One but of advice though, their Margherita pizza is just a cheese pizza with basil strips, it's good, but the first time I got it I was looking for the tomatoes on top (apparently when it says tomato on the menu they mean tomato sauce).  In the scheme of things not a big complaint, but  something to be aware of, if you're a tomato lover.  The staff seems hit or miss, but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt considering the bizarre times I've been eating there (shift changes etc).I'm not sold that it's a life changing Italian restaurant, but they're pizzas are unique and worth stopping in, and taking back home, if your in the neighborhood.

Reviews.Author: Lisa T.
Reviews.Content: I love Baraonda because its my go to place when I need a pick me up (I work close by but I'd go here even if I didn't).  What's super good: I get the Rucola Salad all the time! It's really fresh with arugula, and the shaved  parmigiano, carmalized shallots, and bits of pancetta give it really good flavor. The lemon olive oil is makes it super light.  I also love the Carpaccio and it's only $10 (cheapest I've ever seen).  Lasagna is great, it looks small but is very filling. Butternut squash ravioli was light and not too sweet.Not so good: My sister got the Gargenelli Pasta..if you like sauce do not get this.  The Tomato Basil Soup is a little too salty.I like the atmosphere...very loud but fun.  There's an outside patio, bar, and 2 dining rooms.  Service is usually very nice...sometimes slow so if you're getting pasta don't be in a rush.

Reviews.Author: Timber W.
Reviews.Content: I have no idea why I've been to Baraonda more than once.  Most recently, one of my friends suggested we go there with a group.  I decided to go with the flow and kept my protests to myself.  This proved to be a mistake.  The service was terribly slow and neglectful.  My asparagus risotto was bland and unimpressive, and I had no water in my glass to help force the tasteless arborio rice down my throat.  I'm not sure any of my companions enjoyed their food.  Next time, I intend to speak up the millisecond after a person suggests this place.

Reviews.Author: Tiffany D.
Reviews.Content: Came here on New years night, it was about 10:45 and they close at 11. With it being so close to closing my husband and I still got great service. We started with the Calamari which was cooked perfect. I really enjoyed the ceaser salad and I like anchovies so having it on the salad made it even better. For our main course my husband got the lasagna, which he said it was the best he had ever had( I tried some and it was great!), I got the Tagliatelle Fungi which is 3 different mushrooms with pasta in a light cream sauce. WOW, so good. The atmosphere was good, service great, food great. I will be back because I want to try some of the pizza.

Reviews.Author: J. B.
Reviews.Content: I got turned on to Baraonda by some friends of mine from Italy who worked there.  They were telling me that the food there was really close to where they live in Italy.  Well since I have been to Italy, and wanted real Italian food...I decided to give it a try!  Yes, they were right...it was delicious!  I do wish their food menu had more selections, but I LOVE the pizza there. That is all I ate in Italy when I went, and now I can have it here in the ATL. Who would have known!!  After living in NYC for a while and being able to get any type of pizza I want...this will definitely do the trick for me! Grazie Baraonda!Also if you are going to a show at The Fox, make a reservation here before or after the show!

Reviews.Author: Maressa M.
Reviews.Content: This is a cute little wine bar just down the street from The Fox.  If you want to miss the dinner theater crowd, plan on coming after 7:30.  We had the place practically to ourselves on a Friday night.  The food wasn't bad, but I didn't find anything exceptional or innovative on the menu.  I ordered the white pizza with sun dried tomatoes, and that ended up being better than the other pasta and meat dishes that everyone else tried.     I think the selling point for this place is the location and the romantic feel (low lighting, small space).  The few other people eating dinner seemed to be couples.    Some of the other reviews mentioned poor service, but our waitress was great.  This might have had something to do with her not having any other tables to wait on though...

Reviews.Author: Matthew D.
Reviews.Content: Located right next to the Fox Theatre, mentioned because if you want to actually get a table there check to ensure nothing is playing at the Fox.  I wanted to try out Proof & Provision for some libations across the street, so this seemed like a logical choice to grab a little dinner after my bar exploration.Having never been I went basic with some pizza, the Fra Diavolo ~ tomato sauce, spicy salami, mozzarella.  It was good, Antico isn't going to lose any sleep over it, but it was a fine pie, brick oven style, which always seems to had some character to anything it cooks.  The waiter seemed a little put off to serve the table and a few simple requests were forgotten and when reminded he didn't seem annoyed, he just didn't seem to care.Seated at a little table, maneuvering around the pie was a little more work than it should have been.  The service could have made the experience better, but it did the opposite, not offensive, just apathetic.To Recap:The Good:  The food was worthy of going back, if I was seeing a show at the Fox, it would be the perfect spot to hit prior to. The Bad:  Ho-Hum service.  The wine list was nice, but it was all Italian wines (I know, I know, it is an Italian restaurant), it would have been nice to see a few California wines, just a suggestion, not a knock.The Band This Restaurant Most Resembles:  Ra Ra Riot.  A few things stand out and the location for shows is a hit.

Reviews.Author: Stacey D.
Reviews.Content: We went to Baraonda after a movie at The Fox theater on Friday night. We had friends who were already there and luckily we were able to sit at the table next to them on the patio.  In fact the patio was only about 60% full. Since it was not packed out I was surprised to receive the service or lack of, that  we did. Our friends had the same waiter as we did, and he was not nearly as rude or forgetful with them. Maybe we looked funny...Anyway, we gave him our drink order after sitting there for 15 minutes waiting to meet our server. We ordered wine and beer- not too complicated- but yet it took another 20 minutes for our drinks to arrive, in the meantime another waiter stopped to ask us if he could get our drink order... Really? They seemed to be very confused on what table belonged to who. After our drinks finally arrived, our waiter did not ask us if we were ready to order, he just walked off. Another 20 minutes later, we decided to skip ordering food and go across the street. It still took another 20 minutes and me asking two other people to get our check for the wine and the beer.  So in around an hours time, we were able to drink one glass of wine and one beer.  On my way out, I stopped at the restroom, which was dirty and absent of paper towels to dry your hands.I have been to Baraonda before when it was standing room only and have never experienced such a disaster.  I know they get rushed before  events the Fox, but we arrived around 9:30 to a restaurant that was not even remotely full.  No matter what, even when the food is good, if the service is terrible- it ruins the experience.

Reviews.Author: Lawson W.
Reviews.Content: Really good food and ambiance.  The caprese salad and lamb chops were amazing!  The wine selection was great as well.  The service was decent, but could have been better for a restaurant that nice.  Overall a good experience.

Reviews.Author: Karen F.
Reviews.Content: Baraonda Haiku ReviewIs there such a thingas less than great Risotto?Not at Baraonda!

Reviews.Author: L F.
Reviews.Content: Great Food.  Not a great experience.6 of us guys decided to try Baraonda after a networking event nearby.  We were offered a 4-top right away with the expectation that the table next to it was ready to leave ASAP.  This seemed like a good idea until the other table didn't depart as expected.  15 minutes later two of us were still standing there.  A large table in the front window opened up and I asked if we could take it because a new party of 4 was asking if they could have it.  I was assured that the "other table" would be leaving any second.  Then two in our party decided to leave because it "wasn't working out and the place was too noisy."  We said our good-byes in front of the hosts who seemed to understand that their ill-fated plan had cost them two customers and split up our party.  I wondered if this  event would possibly earn us a comped bottle of wine or some show of apology.  Nope.  No apology, nothing comped.Then one in our party asked about staying "gluten free" and the waiter explained that the kitchen could do a nice piece of fish with a salad.  He ended up ordering the sautéed "pollo something" with no flour and pointed to it on the menu. I heard and watched him order.  When dinner was served the waiter brought veal.  My friend, who was directly across the table from me said, "oh, I ordered the chicken."  The waiter bristled and said, "no you ordered the veal!" as he came in close in a menacing kind of way.  This seemed like a stereotypical Italian maneuver (aka The Sapranos) as if to say, "If I say you ordered the veal, you ordered the veal, got it??"My friend backed down immediately and took the veal without further confrontation.  He seemed to enjoy it but later I got to thinking how unfortunate it was that he was forced to take a meal that he didn't order and that he had been bullied by a waiter.  It made me wonder if the waiter was already in trouble for getting orders wrong and he didn't need one more meal sent back because typically a wrong order would be taken back without any question.Again, the food is good.  The dining room with the bar is too loud for intimate conversation.  Sit outside if possible.  I am writing this only so ownership is aware of what their staff is doing.  I am done with Baraonda.

Reviews.Author: Connor L.
Reviews.Content: Location, brick oven pizza and caprese salad are huge hits. Very cool atmosphere... big corner windows and inviting decor -- and VERY FUNNY shirts the staff wears.... make sure to read the quote on the back. Goes something like this:"HEAVEN is where the police are British, the cooks Italian, the mechanics German, the Lovers French, and it is all organized by the Swiss. HELL is wehre the chefs are British, the mechanics are French, the lovers Swiss, the police German, and it is all organized by the Italians" :)

Reviews.Author: Megan E.
Reviews.Content: I've been here twice-once with my husband, and the other time with both my husband and parents when they were in town visiting for a weekend. To keep things short, our first visit wasn't that great. The food was pretty good--although I must say, if you're looking for a traditional margherita pizza with the huge gobs of mozzarella and fresh basil, theirs is not it--but our waiter was mostly MIA and downright weird that it made it hard to enjoy our dinner. Our second visit was 10x better (no sight of the first waiter).  We each ordered something different (the margherita pizza-again, really quite good but not what is to be expected, grilled chicken and fingerlings, ciociare, and veal scaloppine).  Everyone really enjoyed their meals-the flavors were all so great, and the serving sizes are perfect for the price. Our waitress was very attentive and great at giving recommendations. Since it's only a block away from our apartment, I'm sure we'll go here again very soon.

Reviews.Author: Christy M.
Reviews.Content: I had dinner at Baraonda on a Friday before catching a movie with the girls. It was my first visit, and I was pleasantly surprised! First, parking, which can be a nightmare in this part of town. Super convenient, validated parking across the street. The atmosphere in the restaurant is really lovely, kind of a wine-cave sort of feel. The server was prompt and friendly...she kind of disappeared in that good way, where things happen as if by magic, if that makes any sense. Of course, the food is the most important thing, right? We shared the calamari appetizer, and it was awesome. Perfectly fried, very tender and crisp. I'd be tempted to make it my whole meal, actually. But since there are so many tasty things on the menu, I'm glad I didn't.I ended up ordering the liguine pescatore (seafood pasta) and it was amazing! They definitely did not skimp on the seafood - several large shrimp, a half-dozen or more mussels, and loads more of the tender, perfectly cooked calamari. The tomato-ey sauce was just right, not too intense, so the seafood really stole the show. It felt like about 2 pounds of food, honestly probably more than a person ought to eat at once (but like I said, we were going to a movie after, so I had to eat it all. Oh darn.). Overall, it was a great experience, and I'd love to stop in at Baraonda again, maybe before a show at the Fox or just for a nice night out. It was moderately pricy (total before tip for 1/4 app, 1 glass of wine, and my pasta was $31), but all in all, a good value.

Reviews.Author: Ryan C.
Reviews.Content: DON'T EVER GO WHEN THERE IS A FOX THEATER EVENT. Parking is awful and very inconvenient. Also the host is rude and incompetent. She couldn't answer how long the wait would be.
